title: Friday, 13th January, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

PM11:02am

Have a pic

11:02 am
PM11:02am

PM11:03am

PM11:03am

11:03 am

PM11:04am

The unveiling of the new Nintendo Switch console provided some incremental information and an official launch date, March 3rd, but most attention seems to be on price. The RRP of $299 is inline with the top end of expectations ($249-$299) and compares to the lowest spec PS4 at $260 and Xbox One at $240 for US retail. It is $100 less than the PS4 launch price and $200 less the Xbox One launch price. But $50 pricing difference won’t matter so long as the console uniqueness, the rich graphic display promised, the breadth and quality of games, the portability of taking games with you and the new playing experience is good. If not there is the risk that the Switch will go down the path of oblivion to join the ill-fated WiiU. But Nintendo likely understand the risk as evidenced by the aggressive embracing of mobile gaming and in seeking unique offerings. And with the Switch as a hybrid approach to gaming it is certainly unique and untested. Nintendo’s most pioneering days have always been about bringing differentiation to the market when you consider the NES, the N64, the original Wii, and the DS. It is when products offer only small incremental changes with no significant playability changes that they seem to fail as evidenced by the SNES, GameCube and WiiU.

PM11:04am

The broader app strategy and the paid online service can provide additional capabilities and profit streams for Nintendo. After all the online services for Xbox Live Gold and PlayStation plus generated $2.7B sales in 2016 (Source: IHS) and the same would provide incremental opportunities for Nintendo. What about the content? Well the much hoped for Zelda game will be available at launch and the trailer is described as “off the chain” (TechCrunch) and has an open world design which is popular among role playing games in recent times. And with partners we know there are over 80 games in development.

11:04 am
PM11:04am

It is clearly too early to triumph the Switch but it certainly has promise and will provide the latest opportunity to build on Nintendo’s resurgent mobile offering. The success of Pokémon Go appears to have led to renewed confidence in fast tracking this new mobile first and online strategy from Nintendo. The early traction of sales in March will be key of course but the company is taking strategic steps to capitalize on the sweet spot of AR gaming, IP differentiation and cross-platform media content. As such we see the pullback as an opportunity and remain buyers.

PM11:04am

Seems a reasonable analysis

PM11:04am

He says Buy

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Here's UBS's call, which I offer as another call.

BE11:15am

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and California Air Resources Board (CARB) have issued a notice of violation to FCA for allegedly installing engine software in c104k vehicles in the US that can alter the cars' emissions, and for not disclosing that software. By doing so, FCA is accused of violating provisions of the Clean Air Act and according to an EPA statement may be liable for civil penalties and injunctive relief. The affected cars include model year 2014, 2015 and 2016 Jeep Grand Cherokees and Dodge Ram 1500 trucks with 3.0l diesel engines sold in the US. The EPA is still investigating whether or not the emission control devices constitute "defeat devices". In a company press release FCA responded to the allegations by stating it "believes that its emission control systems meet the applicable requirements" and that it intends to work with the incoming administration to resolve the matter.

BE11:15am

We are in no position to assess the merit of the allegations. Based on the EPA's notification letter, the nature of the alleged violations appear similar to those of Volkswagen, though we don't have detailed enough information at this point. Volkswagen has provisioned €18.2bn for its diesel issue, out of which the lion's share relates to the US. At FCA, the number of cars in question represents 19% (104k cars compared to VW's 560k cars) of VW's affected diesel cars, as previously disclosed by the EPA. According to the FT, FCA could be facing a fine of up to $4.6bn.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

Yep, this is the FT citing UBS citing the FT. Value added.

BE11:16am

A core difference to VW's situation is FCA's balance sheet, which leaves less headroom for any potential pay-outs than VW's: FCA is c€6bn net debt whereas VW is c€30bn net cash. A potential fine would put the already ambitious €4-5bn net cash target by 2018 even more at risk.

BE11:16am

Flashes crossing the tape earlier, incidentally, suggesting the French authorities are investigating Renault.

11:17 am

What exactly that means, I've no idea. One assumes regulators investigate things as a routine part of their jobs.

BE11:17am

Have I mentioned I have no clue here? I've no clue here.

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 207.00, up 4 (+1.97%), High: 209.30, Low: 205.20, Volume: 7.65m
11:18 am

11:19 am

BE11:19am

11:19 am

There. Pick a strategy out of that.

BE11:19am

Here's the front page to put that into some kind of context.

BE11:20am

(@Soundbuy: I don't remember that. Got a link?)

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Media stocks underperformed the broader market in 2016 for the first time since 2009, as growth disappointed and structural concerns heightened. Cyclicals in our coverage have lagged the rotation, outperforming defensives by 7% since July 2016, vs. 34% in the broader market. The media sector now trades on a 16.4x 12M PE, a 7% premium vs. the market (historical average premium of 13%) while media cyclicals present a 5% premium to defensives (historical average premium of 19%). We believe this does not price in the broad pick-up in growth, and creates compelling
opportunities, given our expectations of 17%/9% EPS growth in 2017/18 vs. +12%/5% for the market, with attractive yields and FX tailwinds. As a result, we move our Coverage View to Attractive, from Neutral.

BE11:20am

M&A centre stage in TV, Agencies, Events, Outdoor

We believe the recent pick-up in M&A activity could continue in 2017, given the rising importance of content and scale in distribution, while a number of fragmented end-markets (agencies, events, outdoor) could benefit from further in-market consolidation. We see the most likely targets in our coverage as Ascential, Havas, ITV, UBM and Mediaset, assigning 30% M&A weightings in our price target calculations.

BE11:20am

Rekindling the relationship between macro activity and ad spend

Improving macro trends led by the US and EM (global real GDP growth of 3.6% in 2017E after 3% in 2016) should support ad spend. We expect agencies to be the main beneficiaries, but rising input costs could weigh on certain clients. Our regression analysis suggests the relation between macro activity and ad spend still holds, with the exception of the UK in 2016, which could point to significant upside to consensus forecasts.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

CL-Buys: Ascential, ITV, Publicis are our top picks

We add the following onto the Conviction List (CL): Ascential, for its high structural growth and M&A potential at an attractive valuation; ITV, for its content exposure, upside to consensus ad forecasts, M&A potential and low valuation; Publicis, for the turnaround potential, US exposure and prospective buyback at a low valuation. Other changes: Informa, Lagardere and Vivendi off CL; A3, JCDecaux, ProSieben, Relx NV to Buy, from Neutral; Mediaset, UBM down to Neutral; and M6 to Sell, from Neutral.

BE11:21am

And here comes the ITV M&A bid rumour. Hold on to your hats.

BE11:21am

We highlight ITV as a likely takeover candidate in our space, given its content ownership (30% of its revenues), low valuation relative to its history (23% 12m forward P/E discount) and sector, lack of ownership restrictions and GBP weakness (attractive for a foreign buyer). We note that Liberty Global currently owns a 10% stake and its CEO recently noted in a press conference (January 6, 2016) that he sees FTA investments (such as ones Liberty has done in Belgium/Ireland) as more attractive than buying studios, given European content is more fragmented and most of the viewership (70%) is still FTA in Europe.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Meanwhile, I think JP Morgan has the edge in terms of page count.

BE11:22am

Its media review weighs in at 100 pages, with the M&A section sneaking in on page 10.

PM11:22am

(Flaneur -- Fiat have been rather poor at getting their side of the story out -- just furious wire snaps. There is a proper statement somewhere, but don't have link immediately.)

11:22 am
BE11:23am

...... Grey incoming.

BE11:23am

2016 was a year of underperformance for Media & Internet (-5% vs MSCI Europe) after six years of outperformance. While a healthy earnings outlook (JPMe +19%) and average 6% 17E Equity FCF yield are supportive, we see a mixed sector performance in 2017. Macro/top-down themes will play their part, including: 1) any potential investor rotation from ‘bond proxy’ stocks to value, 2) news flow around and the outcome of political elections (e.g. in France, Germany, Netherlands), 3) any impact from previous major events (Brexit, Trump), and 4) as always, overall health of the economy in different countries. That said, our analysis in this reports suggests that while top-down themes will be influential, stock-specific factors will continue to be more important. Our top picks are Springer, ITV, JUST EAT, Publicis, RELX, WPP (all OW). Our least preferred stocks are Wolters and Lagardère (UW).

BE11:23am

Top-down vs bottom-up drivers: 1) Top down: Looking at the correlation of stock price performance with the direction of bond yields, we found little consistent direction of correlation over time; stocks within sub-sectors with similar profiles (e.g. cyclical free TV or defensive professional publishers) often performed differently. While we expect the direction of yields to influence stock performance, we conclude that fundamentals remain more important. Second, we looked at the correlation between GDP/consumer sentiment and ad growth for FTA TV and Ad Agencies. We found that a) consensus NAR expectations imply upside for ITV (JPMe -3% vs. cons -5% in 17E) but appear full for ProSieben (at +2% NAR). In the context of +3.4% global GDP growth in 17E, expectations for WPP/PUB also appear conservative. 2) Bottom-up themes we expect to drive the sector in 2017 include M&A (e.g. next moves by VIV), self-help (e.g. any disposals by SPR), restructuring plans (e.g. PSON, INF), EPS upgrade potential (e.g. RELX on the back of Risk’s accelerating performance), and as always, attractive valuation (WPP; Publicis, ITV).

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Our top picks: 1) While Brexit is an obvious risk, ITV shares are cheap (12.5x 17E P/E) on low expectations, Studios rev growth should be better in 17E (e.g. two series of Hell’s Kitchen), and our economist recently upgraded 17E UK GDP forecast by 0.3ppt. 2) RELX is accelerating its organic revenue growth (from +3% to +4%) with the move to more sophisticated products, has balance sheet capacity for bolt-ons/buybacks, and trades on lower multiples than other defensives. 3) We believe PUB and WPP are competitively well positioned vs consulting companies, that their organic rev growth is more resilient than perceived, and the stocks offer high Eq FCF yields (8.5% and 7.6% 17E, respectively). 4) We expect takeaway food and JUST EAT to prove more resilient than expected, and see the company continuing to deliver top-line growth well above any other stock in the sector. 5) For Axel Springer, we see attractive valuation (10.8x 17E EV/EBITDA) and a turnaround in EBITDA growth (+10% pa 16-18E).

PM11:24am

So, Just Eat is media now?

PM11:24am

11:24 am

BE11:25am

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Despite ITV scrapping its plans to acquire the business, we continue to see Entertainment One as a potential acquisition target given ongoing demand for high-quality content around the globe. Also, Vivendi has seen press speculation about the purchase of a stake in ad agency Havas, fuelled by Havas CEO Bollore announcing that a merger could “make sense” (Reuters Nov 18th). In regard to ITV, we flag that Virgin Media’s CEO Tom Mockridge has rejected press reports that its parent company Liberty Global (already a 10% shareholder in ITV) could seize on weakness in ITV’s share price (Telegraph, Dec 3rd 2016). US players are always to be watched as a potential acquirer, especially given recent FX movements. So far,
M&A activity involving US players has been relatively quiet in the space (with the exception of the Fox’s proposal regarding Sky in December and Discovery’s purchase of the remaining 49% share in Eurosport from TF1 for €490m in July 2015).

11:27 am

There is increasing impetus for a combination of Vodafone [LON:VOD] and Liberty Global’s [NASDAQ:LBYTA] UK businesses, two bankers familiar with the companies’ strategies said.

The strategic rationale for Liberty’s Virgin Media and Vodafone’s mobile-focused businesses to combine is more pressing now than when a UK deal was mooted in early 2016, the bankers said.

Last year, Vodafone and Liberty discussed deals in Germany and the UK but could not agree on price, a source close to the situation said.

Stranger Holdings plc is pleased to announce the successful placing of 84,770,000 new ordinary shares of £0.001 each in the Company (the 'Placing') and the admission of its entire share capital, being 134,770,000 ordinary shares of £0.001 each ('Ordinary Shares'), to the Official List of the UKLA by way of a standard listing under Chapter 14 of the UKLA's Listing Rules and to trading on the London Stock Exchange's main market for listed securities (the 'Admission'). Alfred Henry Corporate Finance Limited ('Alfred Henry') is financial adviser to the Company.

BE11:35am

(@St Andrean: Citi's Inmarsat note came with some very very sharp forecast downgrades, largely based on continuing margin pressure and pockets of excess capacity. Basically saying the business excluding Lightsquared won't grow earnings this year and will miss long-term guidance by a country mile. That might be overly cautious, since it's a "no visibility" argument, but if it's not then consensus expectations would be expected to ratchet down match to the current valuation.)

BE11:36am

So ........ We're a bit news light this morning.

BE11:36am

11:37 am
BE11:37am

In part on this Glasgow rubbish-to-energy project, which seems to be a hospital pass for everyone involved.

PM11:37am

hehehe

BE11:37am

11:37 am
BE11:38am

BE11:38am

Now CS is talking about construction and financing risk

BE11:39am

Surprising to see a grand public-private infrastructure project in Scotland go horribly wrong ..... really really surprising .....

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Here's the upshot.

BE11:39am

Downgrade to Underperform (from Neutral): Downside in energy-from-waste (EfW) is materialising more quickly than we anticipated and we see risk of a potential liability associated with an unconsolidated financing JV. We cut EPS c3-4% on waste earnings and our TP to 680p (from 800p) primarily on our Viridor valuation, including the Greater Manchester contract and Avonmouth EfW.
Risks in energy-from-waste (c30% EV): We see (a) local authority counterparty risk, (b) exposure to competitive pricing risk which our research suggests will intensify from 2020E, (c) execution risk on construction of the Glasgow plant, and (d) financing risk with a potentially expensive new hybrid. We see no drivers of sustainable medium-term upside to pricing.
Peninsula MB joint venture (PMB): We estimate loss of tax credits could reduce EPS c7-10% p.a. going forward. Reported 2013-15 EPS could have been 26-30% lower if PMB were fully consolidated. Any liability to PNN associated with PMB is not yet clear. We see the 75%-owned JV presenting risk to PNN equity value. We would welcome more clarity from Pennon on its economic exposure, potentially through acquisition of its partner's 25% stake.
Bond yields the risk in water (c70% EV): We value SWW at a premium to reflect outperformance vs. peers, but we see bond yields as the main near-term driver for UK Water valuations. Higher RPI inflation is helpful, with every 1% to RPI adding c2% to its equity RAB value, on our numbers. We model flat WACC allowances from 2020E but see a balance of downside risk.
Catalysts and Risks: Q3mar17 trading update Feb. 9th. A potential hybrid issuance could yield c2-5% downside to EPS. The main upside risk is potential M&A, where our blue sky valuation is 920p/share. Pennon could also crystallise value and delever by selling stakes in EfWs, for example.
A steep valuation: With SWW at c1.37x FYmar18E RAB (our DCF valuation), Viridor (exc. JV's) trades at c16.4x EBITDA. With Viridor at our DCF-based £1.9bn (12.1x EBITDA), SWW trades at c1.52x FYmar18E RAB.

BE11:40am

In terms of E2W .....

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Four distinct risks in Energy-from-Waste
■ Counterparty risk: Potential renegotiation risk on the Greater Manchester Waste contract – the largest municipal waste contract in Western Europe – suggest Viridor's long-term contracts may not have fully 'de-risked' the pipeline of assets, in our view.
■ Pricing risk: We anticipate competitive pricing pressure as early as 2020E. We forecast capacity will rise c50% over the coming three years and standard rate landfill tonnage continues to decline. We think pricing could fall as low as £10/tonne in 2020E with c22% downside to EPS, even if only merchant (not contracted) pricing is affected. We continue model £70/tonne from 2021E.
■ Execution risk: Viridor terminated its contract with Interserve on construction of the Glasgow EfW due to missed contractual delivery milestones. Pennon is clear there is no risk to the technology, which is different from a recently abandoned gasification project in NE England, but until the project is complete we see some potential risk on delivery. We value Glasgow at £201m (c48p/share).
■ Financing risk: Pennon has cited a new hybrid bond as one potential option to help finance the £252m Avonmouth energy-from-waste plant. The £300m hybrid raised in 2013 at 6.75% was c7% dilutive to EPS. If Pennon does raise a second hybrid to finance Avonmouth, this could be c2-5% dilutive to EPS.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Operating margins: Increased cost pressure is expected to lead to lower margins this year, as previously indicated. Our assumption is for a 50 basis point margin reduction and we make no change to this.

Pension fund: The actuarial review as at March 2016 is under way and some increase in the deficit from the £572m at March 2013 is expected. Discussions continue with the pension fund trustees and we would expect the new recovery plan to be announced in Q2 of 2017. We do not expect any material change to the payment plan, which is currently £45m per annum.
Outlook, Forecasts: Management is encouraged by the performance. We make no change to our forecasts.
Valuation: This is an encouraging update today, demonstrating that management action is having a positive impact on sales. The shares have attractions for deep value investors given the low rating of 7.3x earnings and freehold asset backing (NAV of 386p per share before deferred tax) although short-term earnings growth is likely to be unexciting. The unusual share register increases the chances of corporate activity.

BE11:49am
